Electrocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) is one of the important ways to achieve the goal of CO2 utilization and synthesizing high-value products. Electrochemical CO2RR involves multiple electron-proton transfer steps, resulting in low yield and low selectivity. *CO is considered as the key intermediate, the process of CO2RR can be divided into a tandem step of CO2-to-CO and CO-to-C2+. To promote kinetic rate of whole reaction and improve faraday efficiency of the product, tandem catalysts are constructed. Here, the recent advances in application of tandem catalyst for electrocatalytic CO2RR are reviewed for three aspects: (1) tandem mechanism of electrochemical CO2RR; (2) copper-based tandem catalysts as well as other copper-free tandem catalysts for electrochemical CO2RR; (3) challenges, opportunities and prospects of tandem catalysts for CO2RR. This review provides a comprehensive understanding tandem electrocatalytic mechanism of tandem catalysts for CO2RR and important guidelines for the field of electrocatalysis. Graphic abstract Copper-based and other copper-free tandem catalysts for electrocatalytic CO2 reduction Image, graphical abstract Keywords Tandem catalyst Electrocatalysis CO2 reduction Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction With the accelerated development of industrialization and urbanization, energy and environment problems have become the focus of attention. As a renewable carbon resource, CO2 has attracted extensive attention [1,2]. To solve severe energy crisis and environmental problems, China has committed itself to achieve the target of carbon dioxide emission peak before 2030 and carbon neutrality before 2060. In order to achieve this goal, catalytic conversion of CO2 into high-value products or liquid fuels through CO2 reduction reaction supports a sustainable development path [3,4]. Despite of advantage properties including cheap, nontoxic and abundant, the structure of CO2 is highly stable (ΔG=−394.4 kJ/mol). The carbon atom in carbon dioxide is in the highest oxidation state, meaning kinetically inert and inactive properties. Therefore, the conversion of CO2 into high-value chemicals or liquid fuels requires a high activation energy. It is necessary to add a high-energy reducing agent (e.g., H2) or an energy assist (e.g., electricity or light) to break stable CO bond in CO2 reduction reaction. Recently, electrochemical reduction reaction (CO2RR) has been widely investigated due to its advantages such as mild reaction condition, product adjustability, simple operation and strong practicality [5]. And it effectively promote conversion of CO2, considered as a promising way for solving the energy crisis and environmental problem [6]. As is known, some chemical reactions consist of multiple reaction steps, where the product of previous step reaction is the reactant of next step reaction. Two or more independent reactions successively occur. These reactions are called tandem reactions. The concept of “tandem catalyst” was correspondingly proposed in the field of homogeneous catalysis at the end of the 20th century. Different active centers over tandem catalyst cooperate with each other to achieve the mutual conversion of reactants and products [7,8]. Tandem catalyst relies on the cooperation between the active sites of two or more catalysts in separate reaction. Thus, the synergy between coupling reactions can be carried out efficiently. Due to its unique advantages, tandem catalyst has been widely used in various fields in recent years [9]. All catalysts involved in the reaction are added to the catalytic reaction system and there is no need to add another catalyst again during the whole reaction process, which reduces the reaction steps and optimizes the reaction process. From the perspective of thermodynamics, tandem catalyst changes the chemical balance by affecting the reaction intermediates. These generated reaction intermediates in the first reaction are immediately transferred to active sites for subsequent reaction, which improves the utilization rate of reaction intermediates and promotes the reaction activity. By coupling multiple chemical reactions, tandem catalyst could change the thermodynamic condition of single reaction, promote the kinetic rate of whole reaction and improve the faraday efficiency of the product. Electrochemical CO2RR involves multiple electron-proton transfer steps, resulting in different kinds of products, such as C1 products (CO, HCOOH, CH4, etc.), C2 products (C2H4, C2H5OH, etc.) and other multi-carbon products [10–13]. For synthesis of multi-carbon products in CO2RR, *CO is considered as the key intermediate. It means the process of CO2RR can be divided into a tandem step of CO2-to-CO and CO-to- C2+. Copper has been proved to be the only metal catalyst that can effectively convert CO2 into multi-hydrocarbons due to the suitable adsorption capacity for *CO. Despite of this, pure copper also shows drawbacks of low selectivity, poor stability and high overpotential [14,15]. In order to overcome these shortcomings, copper-based and other copper-free tandem catalysts are both used to enhance the kinetic rate of CO2-to-CO and CO-to-C2+ respectively, which contributes to superior electrochemical performance for CO2RR. In this work, recent advances in application of tandem catalyst in electrocatalytic CO2RR are reviewed (Fig. 1 ). Firstly, the tandem mechanism of electrochemical CO2RR is introduced systematically. Secondly, copper-based tandem catalysts and other copper-free tandem catalysts for electrochemical CO2RR are summarized and compared. Finally, the challenges, opportunities and prospects of tandem catalysts for CO2RR are stated comprehensively. 2 Application of tandem catalysts in electrocatalytic CO2 reduction In recent years, with the in-depth study on catalytic activity and selectivity of electrocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction, many kinds and structures of materials have been developed. Copper based catalyst has become a research hotspot in related directions in recent years due to its excellent CO2RR performance. Copper based catalyst can directly reduce CO2 to multi-carbon products, but it has high overpotential and low selectivity [16]. The faraday efficiency of generating other products except CO and formate is not high, and CO2 cannot be effectively reduced to high value-added products to achieve greater economic value and mitigate the greenhouse effect caused by CO2 emission [17–19]. Through rational design and synthesis of electrocatalytic CO2RR catalysts with high selectivity, low overpotential and high stability, the relevant problems can be better solved, and the copper base tandem catalyst has made a breakthrough in solving the relevant problems [20]. The copper based tandem catalyst can efficiently catalyst electrochemical CO2RR by dividing the CO2 C2+ reaction into two independent reactions, CO2 CO and COC2+, and the active sites of the two independent reactions through synergistic interaction, which is the basis for the construction of tandem catalytic mechanism. Copper based series catalysis under the guidance of this theory can be applied to practical CO2RR also gradually proved. It has been proved that Au, Ag, Zn and Pd are ideal catalysts for CO2RR to produce CO. However, Au and Pd have high cost and low abundance, and are costly in industrial applications. Ag and Zn can be applied on a large scale due to their low cost and high abundance. It has also been proved step by step that a series catalyst composed of metals such as Au and Ag with low adsorption to CO and Cu with high adsorption to CO can catalyze CO2 efficiently [21–23]. In the copper based series catalyst, the selection of co-catalyst that can more effectively convert CO2 to *CO (such as Au and Ag, Zn, Pd) and the copper combination with has a stronger adsorption effect on *CO can efficiently reduce CO2 to multi-carbon products. Zhang et al. [24] used the one-pot tandem catalytic mechanism to enable the reaction to carry out one-pot reduction of other products except CO and formate . The results of model construction and theoretical study and calculation of carbon monoxide spillover prove that further reduction of CO from silver or gold substrate to surface Cu is feasible both thermodynamically and kinetically. Therefore, one-pot tandem reduction of CO2 is theoretically feasible. The CO2RR mechanism explored in this study is also applicable to most copper based tandem catalysts, where CO2 is first reduced to CO on the Co-producing substrates Au and Ag, and the CO then spills over and transfers to surface Cu, where it is further reduced to CH4 and other products. In the CO2RR process, metals such as Au and Ag can efficiently catalyze CO2 into CO and have low adsorption energy for intermediate product *CO, which is conducive to increasing the local concentration of *CO, while Cu has medium adsorption energy for *CO and weak adsorption energy for *H. Cu can efficiently convert the adsorbed CO into other products, inhibit HER competing with CO2RR, reduce the energy barrier of CC coupling, and improve the yield and selectivity of C2+ products. This provides a theoretical basis for the preparation of tandem catalysts by adjusting the adsorption strength of the intermediate products produced by two independent reactions of CO2 CO and COC2+ at the two catalytic active sites, and using the spillover effect to transfer CO. 2.1 Cu-based tandem catalysts 2.1.1 Cu-Cu tandem catalysts By means of grain boundary regulation [25], core-shell structure [26], skeleton structure [27], alloying [28], morphology control [29] and oxygen engineering [30] of the two components of the tandem catalyst, the catalytic performance can be changed, and the yield and selectivity of CO2-generated multi-carbon products can be improved. Copper tandem catalyst can catalyze electrochemical CO2RR efficiently by synergistic action of two independent reactive sites. Cu can also be used as a catalyst for CO2 CO reaction to efficiently catalyze the reduction of CO2 to CO, and the CO transfer to the surface of Cu for further reduction. Grain boundary engineering is an effective means to improve catalytic activity of catalysts [31]. Luo et al. [32] proved that grain boundary regulation of metals in CO2RR can improve the yield and selectivity of multi-carbon products by introducing grain boundaries into Cu-based catalysts. Polycrystalline Cu catalysts generally have higher multi-carbon product selectivity and activity than single crystalline Cu catalysts. The tandem catalyst on adjacent active motifs of Cu grain boundaries is the main reason for the enhancement of the activity of CO2 to produce multi-carbon products. The Cu atoms are disordered near the Cu grain boundary, so there are more geometric sites than the single crystal Cu(100) plane. The bonding length of Cu atom at the grain boundary is shorter, which is conducive to bonding with CO. It can better bind CO near the grain boundary, promote the coupling of CC, enhance the activation ability of CO2 to CO, and improve the selectivity of the active site of Cu grain boundary to multi-carbon products. Heteroatomic doping can form better active sites than undoped catalysts and change the properties of catalysts [33]. For example, the co-doping of Cu and N will form the active site of Cu-N4, showing higher CO2RR activity and selectivity. Therefore, the co-doping structure is of great significance for the design of high efficiency catalysts for CO2RR [34]. Chen et al. [35] studied a new type of tandem electrocatalyst Cu-S1N3 /Cux, namely single Cu site with N and S anchored carbon matrix (Cu-S1N3) and Cu cluster (Cux), and found that the main obstacle of CO2 reduction to CO is the huge energy barrier formed by *COOH, which makes the faraday efficiency of CO2 reduction to CO very low. However, the integrated single Cu atoms and Cu clusters in the carbon matrix can reduce the energy barrier of the rate-determining step (*COOH formation) and improve the faraday efficiency of CO2 reduction to CO. The Cu-S1N3/Cux catalyst represents a significant innovation compared to the common Cu-N4 catalyst. The Cu-S1N3 atomic interface with an asymmetric carbon base plane can optimize the bonding energy, thereby enhancing the chemisorption of *COOH, a key intermediate in the reduction of CO2 to CO, and reducing the energy barrier formed by the intermediate *COOH. The highest faraday efficiency of this new electrocatalyst for the reduction of CO2 to CO is 100 %, which provides a new idea for the study of co-doped copper base tandem catalysts. The synergistic effect of multiple sites is an important reason for improving catalyst performance [36]. In recent years, studies have been conducted on how multicomponent heterogeneous catalysts improve catalytic performance through the synergistic effect of multiple sites. Xiong et al. [37] mainly studied on improving the catalytic performance of multi-component polyphase catalysts through the synergistic interaction of multiple sites. The CHK-cOCTA nanoreactor has more Cu-N4/Cu2O/Cu active site, and the active sites of many components constitute the copper tandem catalytic mechanism and the porous structure of the precursor. The faraday efficiency of generating multi-carbon products is close to 80 %, and the faraday efficiency of generating CH4 is as high as 60 %. In the Cu-based nanoreactor, CO2 is first reduced to a large amount of CO at the Cu-N4 site, and then the CO is transferred to the Cu2O/Cu site for further reduction, thus effectively reducing CO2 to CH4 on the surface of Cu2O(111). This study provides a detailed description of synergies, codoping and crystal planes of tandem catalyst involving multi-component active sites. 2.1.2 Cu-Ag tandem catalysts The two active components of the Cu-based tandem catalyst have independent roles in CO2RR. The first active component has low adsorption energy for CO, which can efficiently catalyst the conversion of CO2 into CO. The second active component is Cu with different morphologic and structural, and Cu has moderate adsorption energy for CO, which can be adsorbed and transferred to the surface of Cu for further reduction. Different Copper tandem catalysts have different activity and selectivity of CO2RR under different reaction conditions, mainly due to the different key intermediates of the reaction, the reaction path of forming multi-carbon products is naturally different. At present, most known copper tandem catalysts are used to reduce CO2 to produce high value-added products. By changing the first active component of the tandem catalyst, adjusting the morphology and crystal surface and other factors of the catalyst and carry out various modifications. Different reaction conditions were also changed to explore the catalytic activity and selectivity of copper-based series catalysts in CO2RR with different active components and reaction conditions. Ag is widely used to prepare copper - based tandem catalysts due to its low cost and high abundance. A large number of studies have found that some tandem catalysts are beneficial to the formation of hydrocarbons and some to the formation of oxygen-containing compounds. The Cu-Ag tandem catalysts showed high catalytic activity in CO2RR, and the Cu-Ag tandem catalysts showed different selectivity for different products under different structures and reaction conditions. The hydrocarbon produced by CO2RR has high economic value and practical significance, and has become a research hotspot in recent years. Huang et al. [38] found that the catalytic activity of Ag-Cu nano-dimer was significantly higher than the activity of Ag and Cu two single components, and Ag-Cu nano-dimer had high selectivity for C2H4. When Ag NPs and Cu NPs were combined in the form of nano-dimer, the Ag domain provided a large amount of CO to the adjacent Cu domain. In the Cu domain, a large amount of CO is converted to C2H4, resulting in tandem catalytic and electronic effects between the two components, and when the two metals are mixed at the nanoscale, the two effects are combined, so the tandem catalytic and electronic effects improve the catalytic activity of Ag-Cu nanodimer in CO2RR and the selectivity of C2H4. Shu et al. [39] developed an Ag-Cu dual-cathode CO2RR cell that could independently control the electrode potential, which had higher hydrocarbon yield and reduced the starting potential of hydrocarbon generation on Cu compared to single-copper cathode cells. This is mainly because the CO produced by the Ag cathode transfers to Cu, increases the CO coverage on the surface of Cu, makes the CO coupled with the surface intermediate products, promotes the CC coupling, is conducive to the generation of ethylene, improves the hydrocarbon production rate and hydrocarbon selectivity. The faraday efficiency of CuAg-0.75 % catalyst prepared by Tang et al. [40], which reduced CO2 to CH3CH2OH at −0.71 V, increased by 21.0 %. The possible reaction mechanism of CO2 reduction to CH3CH2OH is shown in Fig. 2 . Tania Akter et al. [41] carried out electrochemical CO2 reduction on a tandem electrode composed of Ag nanoparticles, Cu nanoparticles and proton permeating membrane, the Faraday efficiency of producing C2H4 is up to 80 %, which laid a framework for the selective production of high value-added products by using tandem electrocatalytic CO2 reduction modified by membrane. All these studies have proved the significance of tandem catalyst mechanism in practical application. By changing the structure of the catalyst, the selectivity of the catalyst can be improved by preparing crystal faces conducive to the generation of target products [42,43] . Liu et al. [44] found that Ag-Cu catalyst with pyramid structure was conducive to effectively transfer CO generated on Ag to Cu to generate more reduction products, and this catalyst had high selectivity for CH4. The structure is shown in Fig. 3 The catalyst support of Si(100) is etched into a textured surface consisting of a pyramid structure with a micron size and the {111} surface, while Cu is deposited only on the {111} surface of the pyramid, which improves the proportion of Cu{111} surface and thus facilitates the generation of C1 product. Adjusting the microstructure of copper-based tandem catalyst is an effective method to change the electrochemical CO2RR performance, and the influences between microstructure and induced multi-microenvironment changes have an impact on the performance of CO2RR, but the specific effects need to be analyzed in combination with different structures [45]. Catalysts with porous structure expose a large number of active sites that are attributing to their high specific surface area, which is conducive to improving the performance of the catalyst [46,47]. Sumit Verma et al. [48] found that nano-porous Cu-Ag alloy films have high specific surface area, which improves the activity of CO2RR and the selectivity of C2 products, and the faraday efficiency of C2H4 and C2H5OH generation is 60 % and 25 %. Due to the addition of Ag, Ag promotes the formation of a stable Cu2O coating in the catalytic reaction, and Ag can produce a large amount of CO, which transfers a large amount of CO to Cu.This phenomenon promotes the coupling of CC bonds.At the same time, it improves the CO2RR activity and the selectivity of C2 products. At present, the main product of most known copper - based tandem catalysts is hydrocarbon, with little carbon oxide. Clark et al. [49] found that the compression strain of CuAg surface alloy would improve the selectivity of carbon oxides which produced by CO2RR. In CuAg surface alloys, Ag induces compression strain in the atoms on the surface of Cu.It leads to a significant shift in the valence band structure of copper to a deeper level, which weakens the binding energy of H and O, inhibits HER reaction and the oxygen affinity of Cu, improves the faraday efficiency of C2 products, and facilitates the generation of products containing multi-carbon groups. It reduces the proportion of hydrocarbons that are produced. Wang et al. [50] prepared a flat CuAg electrode with low overpotential by immersing polycrystalline copper foil in diluted AgNO3 solution, which showed high selectivity for acetaldehyde. Under alkaline conditions, nearly 90 % of CO produced by Ag was converted into acetaldehyde, and the faraday efficiency of acetaldehyde generation was 50 %. The selectivity and activity to acetaldehyde can be further improved by increasing the surface area of CuAg electrode. Studies have shown that Ag atom can regulate the surface binding energy of the reducing aldehyde intermediates in CO2RR, thus inhibiting the oxidation of carbonyl group, avoiding the oxidation of acetaldehyde to ethanol, and improving the selectivity of acetaldehyde. Morphology is an important factor affecting catalyst performance, among which core-shell structure has a wide application prospect in electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 due to its unique structure [17,26,51,52]. Chang et al. [53] prepared Ag@Cu bimetallic catalyst prepared by polyol method had better AgCu mixed active sites, achieved the optimal CO binding strength. It made CO reach the peak activity and promoted the generation of CO. With the extension of the reaction time of Ag@Cu catalyst, Cu coating appears on the surface of Ag@Cu. At this time, the main catalytic center is the strain effect of the tensile surface lattice between Cu, Ag and Cu atoms which changes the adsorption energy of the reaction intermediates. The results show that the binding energy between metals and intermediates can be adjusted and optimized by geometric effects to promote the formation of CO and hydrocarbons. This study provides research ideas for Ag-Cu core-shell tandem catalysts, and provides further insights for the design of core-shell CO2 electrochemical reduction catalysts. 2.1.3 Cu-Au tandem catalysts Au has been proved to have the best catalytic performance of CO2RR, and has high selectivity and stability for CO2 reduction to CO under low overpotential, high current density and long-term use [54,55]. However, the cost of Au is expensive and the cost of practical application is too high, so there are not many studies on the preparation of copper-based tandem catalysts using Au. As the main side reaction of CO2RR in electrolyte, HER can be inhibited by increasing the energy barrier of H2 formation and regulating the diffusion of electrolyte to the surface of electrocatalyst, so as to improve the yield of CO2 reduction of multi-carbon products [56]. Secondly, the proximity of adjacent catalytic sites in CO2RR indicates that it can regulate the coupling efficiency of multiple carbon atoms to enhance the yield of multi-carbon products, which indicates the research direction for designing efficient catalysts [57]. Earlier literature showed that Jia et al. [58] prepared a novel nanostructured Cu-Au alloy using nanoporous Cu film (NCF) as a template in order to study electrochemical CO2 reduction in 0.5 M KHCO3 aqueous solution. The faraday efficiency of CO2 reduction to CH3OH on Cu63.9Au36.1/NCF was 15.9 %. It is about 19 times that of pure Cu. The faraday efficiency of CH3CH2OH is increased to 12 %. The improvement of faraday efficiency of CO2 reduction to alcohol may be due to the fact that Cu-Au alloy promotes the formation of alcohol by catalyzing the conversion of intermediate *CO, but the catalytic mechanism of Cu-Au alloy remains unclear. Dohyung Kim et al. [59] found that the activity of gold-copper bimetallic nanoparticles is determined by electronic effects and geometric effects, and the interaction between intermediates and catalysts can be determined by balancing the effects of these two effects, so as to obtain better CO2RR activity and selectivity. In order to improve the catalytic activity and selectivity of copper-based tandem catalysts for electrochemical reduction of CO2 to produce multi-carbon products such as ethylene, ethanol and n-propanol, oxide-derived copper electrode is one of the best electrocatalysts. Most of the early literature referred to tandem catalysts as bimetallic catalysts. Gao et al. [60] synthesized CuAu bimetallic catalyst and optimized it, and the selectivity of oxidized CuAu catalyst in electrochemical reduction of CO2 to produce ethylene, ethanol and n-propyl alcohol was significantly improved. As shown in Fig. 4 , the presence of Au in the bimetallic catalyst helps to enhance the *CO covering concentration on Cu and reduce the CC coupling barrier, thus promoting the formation of olefin and alcohol. Meanwhile, high concentration of *CO inhibited HER. This earlier paper showed the mechanism of tandem catalyst and the importance of * CO covering concentration on the selectivity of C2+ products generated by CuAu catalyst, and pointed out the research direction for the subsequent design of bimetallic catalysts to improve the selectivity of multi-carbon products. The catalytic performance of bimetallic nanocrystals is usually superior to that of single metallic nanocrystals due to the electronic coupling and geometric effects of two different metals. Jia et al. [61] synthesized Au-Cu Janus nanocrystals by growing Cu nanodomains on Au nanocrystals. The asymmetric Au-Cu hybrid nanostructure promoted the conversion of CO2 to C2 hydrocarbons, and its faraday efficiency was 4.1 times that of single metal Cu. The catalytic mechanism is shown in Fig. 5 . Different asymmetric Au-Cu hybrid nanostructures can be obtained by this growth method, which is helpful for the study of structure-function relationship in catalytic process and efficient polyphase electrocatalysts. 2.1.4 Cu-Zn tandem catalysts Electrochemical reduction of CO2 to C2H5OH and C2H4 is an important way for industrial production of chemical products. There are abundant CO2 resources in the atmosphere, and this method can greatly reduce the cost. However, compared with C2H4, most catalysts have low faraday efficiency in catalyzing CO2 to produce C2H5OH. In order to significantly increase the production of C2H5OH relative to C2H4, we need to develop new high-efficiency catalysts to improve the selectivity of electric reduction of CO2 to C2H5OH. The use of cupric tandem catalysts to improve the selectivity of a substance for CO2 reduction can be achieved by introducing an auxiliary catalyst as an in situ source for the generation of moving CO reactants, so that Cu can adsorb more CO, thus improving the activity and selectivity of electrochemical CO2 reduction [62]. Zn is abundant and low cost, and can be used in industrial production on a large scale. Ren et al. [63] prepared CuxZn oxide bimetallic catalysts with different zinc contents in order to improve the selectivity of electrochemical CO2 reduction to C2H5OH, and compared them with Cu-Ni and Cu-Ag bimetallic catalysts, proving the importance of Zn as the site of CO formation. The highest faraday efficiency of ethanol generation on Cu4Zn is 29.1 %. In previous studies, the role of CO in improving the selectivity of ethanol has not been fully elucidated. This paper points out the mechanism of Cu and Zn atoms promoting the electric reduction of CO2 to C2H5OH through synergistic interaction on CuxZn catalyst and the effect of CO. As shown in Fig. 6 , the role of Zn is to produce CO and improve the flux of CO transferred to the surface of Cu. The insertion of a mobile CO into the bond between Cu and *CH2 makes it easier for CO to be produced at the Zn site of the CuxZn catalyst, thereby enhancing the reduction of CO2 to ethanol and improving the selectivity of ethanol. This use of bimetallic catalysts points the way to efficient reduction of CO2 to C2H5OH. Catalysts composed of Cu and Zn, which are abundant in metals, are attracting more and more research due to their low cost and easy availability. Seyedeh Behnaz Varandili et al. [64] prepared a continuously evolving catalyst using customized Cu/ZnO pre-catalyst. Cu@ZnO nanocrystals and ZnO@Cu nanocrystals evolved into Cu@CuZn core-shell catalysts and evolved to alloy CuZn, respectively. The faraday efficiency of methane and ethanol generation is 52 % and 39 %, respectively. The results show that the electron effect and tandem effect are the main reasons for the improvement of selectivity. The lower degree of alloying of CuZn bimetallic catalyst improves the selectivity of CH4, and the higher degree of surface alloying and higher concentration of metal Zn improves the selectivity of C2H5OH. The results show that the catalyst composition is not the only factor affecting the catalyst performance, and the local structure also has a great influence on the catalyst performance. Under the condition of strong catalytic equilibrium, catalysts with the same composition will evolve into catalysts with different structures. The development of new bimetallic catalysts using the synergistic effect between tandem effect and electron effect provides a new synthesis strategy to improve the selectivity of catalysts. 2.1.5 Cu-Pd tandem catalyst Pd is one of the most effective catalysts for the electrochemical reduction of CO2 to formate (a valuable liquid product) at low overpotential. However, Pd inherent high CO affinity makes the surface susceptible to CO poisoning, resulting in rapid catalyst deactivation during CO2 electric reduction. Cu is the only metal capable of reducing CO2 to a range of hydrocarbons or oxides. The surface structure of Cu electrode will affect the catalytic performance of CO2 reduction. The crystal plane is an important factor affecting the selectivity of the catalyst in CO2RR. Cu(111) is conducive to the formation of CH4, Cu(100) is conducive to the formation of C2H4, and the high exponent plane is conducive to the formation of C2+ products. The C2H4/CH4 of Cu(610) and Cu(711) is 5–10 times higher than that of Cu(100). It seriously restricts the further application and development of Pd. According to the properties of Cu and Pd, we can prepare tandem catalysts to make up for the deficiency of the two metals as catalysts alone, and improve the activity and selectivity of CO2RR [65]. Zhang et al. [66] synthesized Cu-covered tetrahexahedral Pd nanocrystal catalyst with {310} high refractive index surfac, which showed high faraday efficiency for alcohols in electrochemical CO2RR. Pd(310) has a strong adsorption on CO. By changing the Cu coverage on Pd(310), the CO adsorption energy can be effectively adjusted to promote CC coupling and improve the yield of alcohol. However, the understanding of the reaction mechanism at this time is still unclear. Gao et al. [67] found that in the electrochemical CO2RR process, the metal Pd surface can promote the generation of CO through *COOH intermediates, and the faraday efficiency of CO generation is more than 90 %, which lays a foundation for the construction of copper-based tandem catalysts using Pd. Due to the electronic coupling and geometric effect between the two metals, the catalytic performance of bimetallic nanocrystals is often better than that of single metal nanocrystals. Lyu et al. [68] synthesized Pd-Cu Janus nanocrystals and generated C2+ products in electrochemical CO2 reduction reaction with faraday efficiency approaching 51.0 %. High CO coverage at the Pd site (metal or hydride form) causes CO to spill over to the Cu site through spillover effect, reducing the CC coupling barrier and promoting the formation of C2+ products. The faraday efficiency of the CuPd bimetallic catalyst developed by Zhu et al. [69] to generate C2+ products in CO2RR was as high as 75.6 %. As shown in Fig. 7 , compared with Cu, the average d-band center of CuPd bimetallic catalyst moves down relative to fermi level, resulting in higher CC coupling activity of adsorbed CO intermediates. CO produced on Pd can spill over to CuPd interface through spillover effect, promoting CC coupling and promoting the generation of C2+ products. This study clearly elucidated the tandem catalyst mechanism of Cu-Pd catalyst. 2.1.6 CuO-Au tandem catalysts In order to improve the catalytic activity and selectivity of Cu based tandem catalysts for reducing CO2 to produce C2 products, oxidation and reduction treatments are often used to modify the surface of Cu to adjust the binding strength of specific intermediates, thus improving the formation rate of C2 products. However, the selective electrosynthesis of C2+ products at the Cu+ interface is severely limited. So there are very few CuO-based tandem catalysts. Zhou et al. [70] synthesized a nanoparticle hollow Au/ CuOCuO tandem catalyst for the catalytic reduction of CO2. The highest faraday efficiency of C2 product was 52.8 % at 1.0 V. As shown in Fig. 8 , this excellent CO2RR performance was due to the fact that in addition to CuO itself reducing CO2 to produce CO/*CO, Au/CuO also generates CO/*CO, and CO/*CO is reduced to C2 products at the reduction site (CuO), that is, a good match between the CO/*CO production site (Au/CuO) and the reduction site (CuO) in terms of the best working potential and charge transfer resistance. This pair matching effect ensures the sufficient supply of CO/*CO and electrons at the CuO site at the working potential, thus promoting the generation of C2 products. This paper points out that the matching of charge transfer resistance is a necessary condition for tandem catalyst. 2.1.7 CuONi tandem catalysts By combining Ni with other substances, different CO2RR catalysts can be prepared by forming coordination structures or hollow fibers, etc. These catalysts show high performance against CO2RR and have high CO faraday efficiency. Moreover, adjusting the surface environment of Ni species can activate the original inert reaction sites into active reaction sites. It provides a promising approach for the design of electrocatalysts with high efficiency for CO2RR [71,72]. The multiple steps of reducing CO2 to C2+ can be divided into two reactions catalyzed by two single catalysts, CO2 CO and COC2+, to form a tandem catalyst to improve the catalytic activity and selectivity of the tandem catalyst. Zhang et al. [73] found that CuO and Ni single atoms constituted a tandem catalyst CuO/Ni. As shown in Fig. 9 , Ni and Cu independently catalyzed two reactions of CO2 CO and Co-C2+, and the catalytic sites of the two reactions were close to each other, which was conducive to in-situ generation and rapid consumption of CO. The faraday efficiency of CO2 reduction to C2+ by CuO/Ni tandem catalyst is 81.4 %, in which the faraday efficiency of ethylene is 54.1 % and that of ethanol is 28.8 %, which provides theoretical guidance for the preparation of tandem catalysts using Ni. 2.1.8 Cu2OCu tan dem catalysts The OD-Cu catalyst obtained from the reduction of Cu oxide has better electrocatalytic CO2RR activity than polycrystalline Cu. It can not only reduce the overpotential of CO2RR, but also has excellent C2 product selectivity in electrocatalysis of CO2RR [74]. However, the structure of Cu2O will undergo complex structural evolution under negative potential conditions, and it is difficult to obtain specific active structure. Yang et al. [75] found that the inert octahedron Cu2O (o-Cu2O) prepared by activating OD-Cu catalyst with cyclic voltammetry (CV) can evolve into active Cu/Cu2O−CV, so that Cu is uniformly anchored to o-Cu2O and accompanied by abundant Cuδ+−Cu0 grain boundaries. Through CV activation process as shown in Fig. 10 , CO*adsorption is enhanced to form O*C*COH intermediates. Compared with o-Cu2O, Cu/Cu2O−CV increases the faraday efficiency of C2 products from 17.13 % to 73.44 %, and that of ethanol from 5.15 % to 56.56 %. The results show that the coupling interaction between the surface-interface CO2 reaction and the structural evolution of Cu2O is beneficial to increase the yield of C2 products. The use of Cu0 and Cu+ is one of the most effective ways to generate C2 products by electrocatalytic CO2RR because it promotes CO2 activation and CC dimerization. Chansol Kim et al. [76] synthesized a new porous Cu/Cu2O aerogel catalyst, which has a high ethanol selectivity in electrocatalytic CO2RR and a faraday efficiency of 41.2 %, which is the catalyst with the best performance of CO2 reduction to ethanol reported at that time. The significant improvement of ethanol production performance is mainly due to the increase of local pH value and Cu/Cu2O tandem mechanism in a large number of Cu0-Cu+ interface and high surface area closed porous aerogel network structure. 2.1.9 Cu2O-Ag tandem catalysts Oxide derived copper catalysts introduce metals such as Ag or Au, which can efficiently generate CO, so that more CO is adsorbed by copper oxides, improving the catalytic performance of CO2 reduction, which is mainly attributed to the regulation effect of oxide types [77]. However, tandem catalysts with different structures are affected by various factors, and the reasons for improving the catalytic performance are different. On the basis of Cu2O catalyst, Ag/Cu2O and Au/Cu2O tandem catalysts can improve the activity of electric CO2RR and the selectivity of certain products. The catalytic performance of Ag/Cu2O and Au/Cu2O tandem catalysts with different morphologies can be improved to different degrees and reasons. Wang et al. [78] studied a novel, layered, flower-like nanostructure of Ag/Cu2O and Au/Cu2O catalysts. The two catalysts used Cu2O as a template, with Ag and Au nanosheets crossing each other and wrapped with Cu2O spheres inside. By changing the atomic ratio of Ag/Cu and Au/Cu, Ag0.125/Cu2O and Au0.6/Cu2O catalysts were prepared. It was found that these two catalysts improved the stability and selectivity of CO compared with Cu2O catalyst. The combination of Ag, Au and Cu2O, The formation of HER and formate competing with CO2RR was relatively inhibited. The layered structure provides a larger electroactive surface area, and the faraday efficiency of CO generation by Au0.6/Cu2O catalyst is 10 % higher than that by Ag0.125/Cu2O catalyst, which provides a new idea for the study of the application of layered metal oxide catalyst in the direction of CO2RR. Niu et al. [79] prepared Cu2O nanocube and Ag nanoparticles into Cu2O-Ag tandem catalyst through displacement reaction. Adding Ag on the basis of Cu2O was beneficial to transfer more CO produced on Ag to the surface of Cu2O, which was beneficial to reduce the barrier energy of CC coupling reaction and promote CC coupling. Improve the selectivity and activity of C2 products produced by CO2RR. The faraday efficiency of Cu2O-Ag tandem catalyst to produce C2 products is 72.85 %, which is higher than the faraday efficiency of Cu2O catalytically converting CO2 into C2 products, but there is still much room for improvement. The C2+ liquid product of electrocatalyzed CO2RR is easier to store and transport than the gaseous product, and can be used in various fields. Antonia Herzog et al. [80]synthesized a Cu2O nanocube catalyst with uniform coverage of Ag nanoparticles. Compared with Cu2O nanocube catalyst, the faraday efficiency of generating C2+ liquid products in the CO2RR process was increased by two times, and the generation of HER and formate was inhibited. The reason for the improvement of faraday efficiency of C2+ liquid products is that Ag-Cu sites are formed during the CO2RR process of the catalyst. The Ag/AgCu/Cu interface as the active surface site is conducive to the effective CO overflow and improve the yield of C2+ liquid products. The catalytic performance of Ag-based catalyst depends on the influence factors of crystal size, morphology, crystal surface and space restriction [81–83]. Introducing Cu in different oxidation states into Ag-based catalyst can adjust the binding structure and binding strength of key reaction intermediates at the interface during the electrochemical reduction of CO2, so as to improve the catalytic activity and adjust the product selectivity. Li et al. [84] prepared a honeycomb Cu2O@Ag catalyst, whose low CO coverage on the surface inhibited HER, thus stabilizing *CHO, a key intermediate in CO2 reduction reaction, and promoting the generation of CH4. The honeycomb Cu2O@Ag catalyst is conducive to the trapping of more CO2 on the Cu2O-Ag interface, which strengthens the physical adsorption and chemical adsorption of CO2 on the catalyst surface and is conducive to CC coupling. The incorporation of Ag atoms into the Cu surface induces compressive strain, weakens the binding energy of H and O, inhibits HER, and thus improves the selectivity of multi-carbon products. Through the analysis of the free energy diagram of CO2 reduction to CO, CH4 and C2H4 gas products with different catalysts in Fig. 11 , it is found that the physical adsorption and chemisorption of CO2 by Cu2O@Ag catalyst improves the CO utilization rate, and the high CO utilization rate is conducive to the formation of methane and ethylene. This study provides a theoretical basis for the development of catalysts that can effectively reduce CO2 by adjusting the binding strength with key intermediates and altering different reaction pathways [85]. The catalyst geometry can affect the activity and selectivity of electrochemical CO2RR. In recent years, it is a hot research direction to explore how to improve the activity of electrochemical CO2RR and the selectivity of certain products by regulating the geometry of catalysts. A variety of catalysts glow and heat in different directions, among which core-shell catalysts are the most important, and breakthrough progress has been made in the field of electrocatalytic CO2RR. Xiong et al. [86] prepared a Ag@Cu2O nanoreactor with yolk shell nanocellular structure including an Ag core and Cu2O shell, which is one of the catalysts with high methane yield in recent years . In the process of reducing CO2 to CH4, *CHO is the key intermediate. CO2 generates *CO on Ag nucleus, and *CO is converted to *CHO on Cu to generate CH4, which fully demonstrates the tandem mechanism of this catalyst. By fixing Ag nuclei and adjusting Cu2O shell size, the flux of CO to the oxid-derived Cu (OD-Cu) shell can be adjusted, and then the *CO covering and *H adsorption on the surface can be adjusted, thus regulating the electrocatalytic CO2RR activity and the selectivity for CH4. Low CO coverage is conducive to the formation of *CHO, which improves the faraday efficiency of CH4 generation. This catalyst has a faraday efficiency of 74±2 % for CH4 generation, higher than that of most catalysts. This study demonstrates the importance of precisely regulating catalyst geometry in the field of electrocatalytic CO2RR and how the distribution of reduction products can be changed by regulating the flux of CO. 2.1.10 Cu2O-Au tandem catalysts In the tandem catalytic mechanism, high concentration of CO can be further reduced by controlling the morphology of Cu2O, and the catalytic performance of CO2RR can be improved. Zhang et al. [87] found that the catalyst Au@Cu2O, composed of Au nanoparticles and Cu2O nanocavity, can selectively reduce CO2 to C2H5OH by limiting CO intermediates. In this tandem catalytic mechanism, the CO produced by Au fills the Cu2O nanocele. Due to the high enough CO concentration produced by the Cu2O nanocele, the copper shell converts CO into C2H5OH and promotes the formation of C2H5OH. The maximum faraday efficiency of C2H5OH reaches 52.3 %. The results showed that the spatial consistency of different active sites was conducive to the formation of C2 products. Tan et al. [88] prepared a hollow cubic Cu2O@Au catalyst by electrodepositing Cu2O cube as a template. The maximum faraday efficiency of CO generation in CO2RR is 30.1 %, which is about twice that of Cu2O and Au electrodes at the same potential. The metal-oxide interface of the hollow cubic Cu2O@Au catalyst can activate inert CO2 molecules, which is conducive to the generation of CO and improve the catalytic activity of CO2RR. Cao et al. [89] explored and found that AuxCu2O, a new Au-modified cubic Cu2O electrocatalyst, has better catalytic activity of CO2RR, and the catalytic mechanism is shown in Fig. 12 . AuxCu2O has enhanced selectivity to C2H4 in CO2RR compared with Cu2O. The highest faraday efficiency of Au0.02Cu2O in reducing CO2 to C2H4 is 24.4 %, which is several times higher than that of the other two AuxCu2O catalysts. The results indicate that the optimal ratio of Au and Cu is a necessary condition for Au and Cu2O to effectively promote the coupling of CC, and the optimal Au load can reduce CO2 to C2H4 more effectively. The valence state of Cu will also affect the selectivity of AuxCu2O catalyst to C2H4. Only the synergistic action between Cu+ and Cu° can effectively improve the selectivity of C2H4, which will provide a new strategy for the effective reduction of CO2 to C2 products by copper oxide bimetallic catalyst. Zhang et al. [90] obtained Aux/Cu2O catalyst by preparing Cu2O hollow nanospheres supported Au nanoparticles. More CO could be generated at the Au site to transfer to Cu2O for reduction to other products, thus promoting CC coupling and improving the selectivity for C2H5OH. This provides an effective method to improve the faraday efficiency of C2H5OH generation using CO2. 2.1.11 Cu2O-Pd tandem catalysts Cu+ is easily reduced in the process of CO2RR, while Cu2O is unstable. Xiao et al. [91] designed and synthesized Pd-Cu2O tandem catalyst in order to make Cu+ stable in Cu2O during CO2RR reduction. Pd can enhance the stability of *CO intermediate and promote CC coupling. The faraday efficiency of C2H4 reaches 63.8 %, which is 1.5 times higher than that of Cu2O catalyst. Due to the high work function of Pd, the electrons on Cu2O spontaneously transfer to Pd, reducing the local electron density, which is conducive to the stability of Cu+ in Cu2O. This feature also lays the foundation for the subsequent preparation of Cu+ modified by Pd and provides a new way to promote electron transfer by using the poor work function. 2.1.12 Cu2O-ZnO tandem catalysts ZnO can reduce CO2 to CO, but its catalytic activity is lower than Ag and Au, so the research significance is not high. Previously, in order to study tandem catalysts with lower cost, tandem catalysts composed of ZnO and different forms of copper by synergistic action can improve the catalytic performance of electrochemical CO2RR. Although the improvement degree is not very high, it provides a theoretical basis for studying the electrochemical catalytic CO2 reduction of ZnO. CH3OH is an important raw material for liquid fuel production. With the wide application of liquid fuel, it is urgent to improve the faraday efficiency of CH3OH production. In order to improve the faraday efficiency of CH3OH formation in aqueous solution, Jonathan Albo et al. [92] designed a Cu2O/ ZnO electrode based on the fact that Cu2O can convert CO2 into CH3OH with high faraday efficiency due to its intermediate hydrogen overpotential and CO adsorption characteristics. The faraday efficiency of electric reduction of CO2 to produce CH3OH by Cu2O/ ZnO electrode in aqueous solution is 17.7 % and has good stability. The results show that there is a synergistic effect between Cu2O and ZnO in the CO2RR process, which makes the Cu2O/ ZnO electrode may be conducive to the conversion of CO2 to CH3OH and improve the selectivity of alcohol, but the specific mechanism is still unclear. Luo et al. [93] found that metallic Zn is the active center for the conversion of CO2 to CO, and because Zn has appropriate binding strength for reaction intermediates (such as *COOH and *H), it has high selectivity for CO. Due to its large specific surface area and stable crystal structure, the ZnO derived catalyst (OD-ZnO) improves the activity of CO2RR and shows higher CO selectivity and stability, with a CO selectivity of more than 90 %. This study also provides a strong support for Cu2O/ ZnO electrodes to improve the faraday efficiency of CH3OH, and also provides a new research direction for the application of tandem catalysts in electric CO2RR. 2.1.13 Cu@metal-organic skeleton tandem catalysts Metal-organic framework is a porous crystalline material composed of metal ions or metal clusters and multi-toothed organic ligands. In recent years, MOFs or MOF composites have been used to prepare tandem catalysts, which have been widely used due to their adjustable open metal centers, functional organic linkers and active objects in pores [94–96]. Zhao et al. [97] prepared tandem catalyst Cu(111)@Cu-THQ by fixing Cu(111) nanoparticles on conductive Cu foundation organic framework (Cu-ThQ), Cu(111)@Cu-THQ reduced CO2 to C2H4 and the faraday efficiency was doubled compared with Cu(111) nanoparticles. The abundant CO migrates from the CuO4 site to the stronger CO binding site on the surface of Cu(111) through spillover, enhancing the local concentration of *CO intermediates on the surface and further reducing CO to C2H4. 2.1.14 Other cu-based tandem catalysts Due to its excellent catalytic performance, cupric tandem catalysts have become a research hotspot in the direction of CO2 reduction. However, most current studies are looking for different metals or metal oxides on the basis of copper as another component of the tandem catalyst. However, in a large number of studies, it has been found that some molecular catalysts can also undertake part of the active component of the tandem catalyst. The efficient catalytic reduction of CO2 to CO increases the local concentration of CO, and transfers CO to copper through the spillover effect by regulating the oxidation state and morphology of copper, indicating further reduction. It is found that molecular catalysts represented by porphyrins as substitutes for heterogeneous catalysts have broad application prospects in CO2RR. Among them, iron porphyrin (Fe-Por) molecular catalysts can be applied in the field of CO2RR [98–100]. Wang et al. [101] prepared Cucub/Fe-Por, a tandem catalyst composed of iron porphyrin (Fe-Por) and Cu nanocube (Cucub). Fe-Por can promote the local accumulation of CO near Cucub, increase the local concentration of CO, and promote CC coupling. Fe-Por can also stabilize the morphology of Cucub. Fe-Por had the highest CO conversion frequency, ethylene selectivity was improved by nearly 22 times, and the faraday efficiency of C2H4 generation by Cucub/Fe-Por was increased by 36 % compared with Cucub. Molecular catalysts have unique advantages over metals in that their electronic and structural characteristics can be adjusted by synthesizing modified cations. The CO conversion rate of the molecular catalyst is directly related to the CC coupling enhancement of the tandem catalyst. The use of molecular catalysts that can efficiently catalyze the reduction of CO2 to CO is an alternative to the metal tandem scheme. In order to improve the selectivity of multi-electron reduction of CO2, the catalytic performance of copper can be changed by adjusting the morphology, size, crystal surface, defects and charge composition of copper. Organic molecular-modified copper catalysts enhance the performance of catalytic reduction of CO2 by regulating the reaction intermediates. Wang et al. [102] combined organic molecules with microporous polytetrafluoroethylene supported copper catalyst to prepare copper based tandem catalyst modified by organic molecules. The faraday efficiency of CO2 reduction to CH4 was 50 %±2 %, and the selectivity of CH4 was 2.7 times higher than that of microporous polytetrafluoroethylene supported copper catalyst. The modification of copper with organic molecules can enhance the protonation of *CO, and the protonation of *CO to *CHO is the key to the formation of CH4, which promotes the formation of CH4. The special structure of organic molecules can provide more protons, inhibit HER, and be more conducive to protonation of *CO. The organic molecules have a large surface area and can provide abundant active sites for surface reactions. This work provides a theoretical basis for preparing tandem catalysts by modifying copper with abundant organic molecular materials. Polymer-modified copper-based catalysts have high multi-electron reduction selectivity in the process of CO2 electric reduction, which has been a hot topic for copper modification to improve the performance of CO2RR in recent years [103,104]. However, the yield of polymer-modified copper-based catalysts for CO2 reduction is very low, and the research progress is slow. Xu et al. [105] synthesized a polyionic liquid (PIL) based Cu(0)-Cu(I) tandem catalyst Cu(0)@PIL@Cu(I), which can catalyze CO2 reduction with high efficiency. The yield of C2+ product was increased to 76.1 %. The Cu(0)-PIL interface generates a large amount of CO into the PIL layer, and the released CO diffusionally accumulates in the PIL layer, resulting in local concentration enrichment of *CO. PIL-Cu (I) interface can promote the CC coupling of locally enriched CO, that is, there is weak intermolecular interaction between PIL layer and key intermediates, reducing the potential barrier of CC coupling. Improve selectivity for C2+ products. Tandem catalysts can improve their catalytic activity and selectivity through local multi-site synergies. However, catalysts often evolve in the process of CO2RR, so it is necessary to further explore the reconstruction, interaction and origin of the activity of the two components in tandem catalysts. Yang et al. [106] synthesized AgI-CuO tandem catalyst for electric reduction of CO2. As shown in Fig. 13 , the leaching I − from AgI was adsorbed on the surface of Cu, which inhibited the entire reduction of CuO, formed rich and highly active Cu0/Cu+ interface, promoted CC coupling through synergistic action, and increased the faraday efficiency of C2+ product to 68.9 %. This paper mainly explores the interaction of two phases in the electrochemical reconstruction process, providing guidance for the control of the active components in the tandem catalyst, and also points out the direction for the efficient generation of C2+ products by the synthesis of tandem catalysts using halogen atoms. A tandem catalyst requires two active sites. The first site can efficiently catalyze the reduction of CO2 to a high concentration of CO, and then the CO is converted to a high value-added product at another site (such as copper) due to spillover effects. At present, several major copper-based tandem catalysts have been reported, and the first site mostly uses Au, Ag, Pd and other precious metals, so the development and use of non-precious metals as the first site of tandem catalysts with high activity has broad application prospects. Cao et al. [107] constructed a tandem electrocatalyst PTF(Ni)/Cu by evenly disperses Cu nanoparticles on porphyrin triazine framework anchored by nickel nitrogen site (PTF(Ni)). The maximum faraday efficiency of reducing CO2 to C2H4 by PTF(Ni)/Cu was 57.3 %. The faraday efficiency of the main product CH4 is 6 times higher than that of non-tandem catalyst PTF/Cu. The Ni site in PTF(Ni)/Cu can rapidly convert CO2 into CO, resulting in high concentration of CO spilling over to Cu site, which is conducive to CO dimerization to C2H4, and inhibits the formation of CH4 and H2. Studies have shown that improving the activity and selectivity of CO2RR by locally adjacent multiple different catalytic sites is an effective tandem catalytic method. Chen et al. [108] prepared a phosphorus-doped Cuδ+ rich catalyst Px-Cu by a one-pot method. The faraday efficiency of C2H4 is 30.7 ± 0.9 %, higher than that of copper catalyst. As shown in Fig. 14 , Px-Cu catalyst transfers electrons from surrounding Cu atoms to P atoms, resulting in changes in electron density between Cu and P atoms, promoting the formation of Cuδ+, and the Cuδ+ group can optimize the adsorption of carbon intermediates and promote CC coupling, promoting the formation of C2H4. Zhang et al. [109] used Cu-N sites and Cu clusters to form a tandem catalyst PDI-Cu /Cu, and compared with non-tandem catalyst PDI/Cu, the faraday efficiency of CO2 reduction to C2H4 was more than 2 times higher. As shown in Fig. 15 , in this tandem reaction mechanism, CO2 is first reduced to a high concentration of CO at the Cu-N site, and then CO overflows to the surface of the Cu cluster due to spillover effect, and the *CO intermediate dimerizes and is further converted to C2H4. The tandem catalyst Ni SACs-Cu NPs encapsulated with Ni single atom prepared by Hu et al. [110] can efficiently reduce CO2 to CH3COOH electrically. As shown in Fig. 16 , Ni single atom reduces CO2 to CO, and CO is transferred to the site of Cu(111) crystal surface, forming a high concentration *CO covering layer. Reduce the CC coupling energy barrier and further promote the formation of CH3COOH. On the basis of a lot of research on the copper base tandem catalyst, the new copper base tandem catalyst CO2RR developed with different materials also has good performance. Jae Chan Lee et al. [111] used electrospinning copper acetate/polyacrylonitrile nanofibers to prepare Cu/NCNF tandem catalyst coated by N-doped carbon nanofibers, which effectively catalyzed the electric reduction of CO2 to C2H4. N-doping can increase the concentration of *CO on Cu surface and reduce the *CO dimerization barrier. The *CO dimer is the rate-determining step of CO2 reduction to C2H4 production, which improves the yield of C2H4. N-doped carbon nanofibers also have the unique role of an electron conduction pathway, which can inhibit the agglomeration of Cu particles. The faraday efficiency of Cu/NCNF tandem catalyst for CO2 reduction to C2H4 is 62 %, which is significantly improved compared with 37 % of undoped carbon nanofibers, indicating that heteroatomic doping and porous carbon carrier is a new synthesis strategy for CO2RR tandem catalyst preparation. In order to develop a cupric tandem catalyst with better performance, modification of copper catalysts with different forms can significantly improve the CO2RR performance of the catalyst, specifically improve the selectivity of reducing CO2 to a certain product, improve the product yield, and create greater value. Graphene materials can efficiently reduce CO2 to CO, while graphene-modified copper can improve the activity of CO2RR and the selectivity of related products through a tandem mechanism [112–116]. Elias Mardones-Herrera et al. [117] synthesized a catalyst Cu NCbs-rGO modified with reduced graphene oxide (rGO). Compared with copper nanocubs, Cu NCbs-rGO improved the selectivity of electric reduction of CO2 to C2H5OH. The faraday efficiency of C2H5OH generation is increased to 76 %. A high concentration of CO can be produced on the surface of Cu nanocube modified with rGO. Through the spillover effect, CO will overflow to the Cu site, which improves the local concentration of CO at the Cu site, promotes the CC coupling, facilitates the conversion of a large amount of CO into C2H5OH, and improves the selectivity for C2H5OH. It provides a new option for how to control the product of CO2RR. 2.2 Other tandem catalysts Due to its excellent CO2RR performance, copper-based tandem catalysts can synthesize abundant and low-cost CO2 into high value-added chemical products and solve environmental and energy problems. It has been a hot spot in electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 in recent years [118]. Copper-based tandem catalysts with different morphologies and structures have been extensively studied. Compared with catalysts of single component, the catalytic activity and selectivity of certain products of these copper base tandem catalysts have been greatly improved, but the research has also entered the bottleneck period, and a lot of innovation is needed to develop new copper base tandem catalysts with good performance. With the exception of copper-based tandem catalysts, there are few other non-copper tandem catalysts that can reduce CO2 to high value-added products. Therefore, the development of non-copper tandem catalysts has great research prospects in the field of CO2RR, which marks a new development stage of CO2RR [119,120]. The reduction of CO2 to hydrocarbons is achieved through the formation of CO intermediates, which is a key step in the production of multi-electron reduction products from CO2 reduction [121]. The performance and selectivity of electrochemical reduction of CO2 are mainly determined by electrocatalyst. Therefore, molecular catalysts represented by phthalocyanine, as substitutes for heterogeneous catalysts, have broad application prospects in the selective conversion of CO2 to hydrocarbons and oxygen-containing compounds. Defining new chemical structures may therefore contribute to a comprehensive understanding of the mechanism of the carbon dioxide reduction process [122]. The molecular structure of cobalt phthalocyanine (CoPc) is an efficient catalyst for the synthesis of CO using CO2 [123–125], and M-N-C material is also an efficient catalyst for the reduction of CO2 to CO with high activity and low cost [126–129], with the transition metal atom coordinated with nitrogen as the active site. However, the tandem catalyst composed of two catalysts has better performance of electric reduction of CO2. Lin et al. [130] prepared the catalyst CoPc©Fe-N-C by anchoring the Fe-N site with cobalt phthalocyanine (CoPc). There is a strong interaction between CoPc and Fe-N-C, which can reduce the inactivation of *CO, promote the desorption of CO, and inhibit HER competing with CO2 reduction reaction at Fe-N site. While the formation of *COOH is not affected, CO generation is promoted through synergistic catalysis, and the faraday efficiency of CO is significantly increased to more than 90 %. Lin et al. [131] synthesized cobalt phthalocyanine (CoPc) and Zn-N-C tandem catalyst CoPc@Zn-N-C. Compared with the two single-component catalysts, the CoPc@Zn-N-C tandem catalyst significantly improved the selectivity and activity of reducing CO2 to CH4, and the yield of CH4 increased by more than 100 times. As shown in Fig. 17 , in a tandem catalytic mechanism, CoPc can reduce CO2 to high-throughput CO, which is transferred to the Zn-N4 site for conversion to CH4. CoPc also has another unique effect, improving the adsorption efficiency of *H at the adjacent N site in Zn-N4, promoting the conversion of *CO to *CHO, and improving the yield of CH4. This study provides a new method to generate CH4 and makes a great contribution to the preparation of CH4 from CO2. In the study, it was found that not all CoPc and M-N-C materials can form tandem catalysts to reduce CO2 to high value-added products, but can improve the performance of CO2 conversion to CO. Du et al. [132] prepared Fe−CO−Pc−Ni−O−COFs catalyst by using the idea of tandem catalyst. The two active sites of NiO4 and Fe−Co−Pc can act independently, that is, CO generated on NiO4 can migrate to the active site of Fe−Co−Pc catalyst spontaneously and quickly, and C2 intermediates can be obtained by coupling C1−C1. C2 intermediates C1−C2 are coupled to produce C3 products. The results show that the coupling of *CO−*CHO is conducive to the formation of C2 products, and the coupling of *CH3CHO and *CO is conducive to the formation of *CH3CHOCO/ n-propyl alcohol. This study provides the best way for the formation of C3 products from CO2RR. 3 Conclusion In summary, tandem catalyst relies on the cooperation between two or more catalysts to combine the active sites of two reactions, showing a high degree of specificity to the coupling between different chemical reactions, so that the synergy between the coupling reactions can be carried out efficiently. Firstly, this paper systematically introduces the series connection of electrochemical CO2RR. Secondly, copper-based tandem catalysts for electrochemical CO2RR and other copper-free tandem catalysts are compared. Table 1 summarizes the electrochemical CO2RR performance of tandem catalysts reported in recent years. In electrochemical CO2 reduction reactions, tandem catalyst breaks the linear proportional relationship of intermediates by adjusting the binding strength of intermediates, and improves the selectivity of target products. Since copper is the only material that can reduce CO2 to multi-carbon products, the tandem catalyst seeks another active site that can generate CO on the basis of copper to prepare the copper-based tandem catalyst, and adjusts and improves the selectivity and activity of electrochemical CO2 reduction to multi-carbon products by changing the composition and morphology of the copper-based catalyst. In addition, great progress has been made in actively exploring materials that can replace copper. tandem catalyst has made remarkable achievements in the field of electrocatalytic CO2 reduction, but we still need to continue to innovate and design tandem catalysts with more efficient performance of electrocatalytic CO2RR. coredata.dc:description: Electrocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) is one of the important ways to achieve the goal of CO2 utilization and synthesizing high-value products. Electrochemical CO2RR involves multiple electron-proton transfer steps, resulting in low yield and low selectivity. *CO is considered as the key intermediate, the process of CO2RR can be divided into a tandem step of CO2-to-CO and CO-to-C2+. To promote kinetic rate of whole reaction and improve faraday efficiency of the product, tandem catalysts are constructed. Here, the recent advances in application of tandem catalyst for electrocatalytic CO2RR are reviewed for three aspects: (1) tandem mechanism of electrochemical CO2RR; (2) copper-based tandem catalysts as well as other copper-free tandem catalysts for electrochemical CO2RR; (3) challenges, opportunities and prospects of tandem catalysts for CO2RR. This review provides a comprehensive understanding tandem electrocatalytic mechanism of tandem catalysts for CO2RR and important guidelines for the field of electrocatalysis.
coredata.dc:title: Recent advances in application of tandem catalyst for electrocatalytic CO2 reduction
